Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop will explore key challenges and opportunities for the development of an open data ecosystem for neuroscience. It will bring together experts from academic, government, and other organizations, and is organized around three themes:
1. Incentives to Share, and What We Could Accomplish
2. Discoverability to Discovery
3. Sustainability: How to Fundamentally Change Science

The workshop is scheduled for July 25-26, 2016, in Washington, D.C. A resulting roadmap will facilitate alignment and coevolution of new and existing data sharing efforts, and powerful new modes of interdisciplinary discovery.

Generous co-funding is provided by the Divisions of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure (CISE/ACI), Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences (SBE/BCS), and Emerging Frontiers (BIO/EF).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Open Data Ecosystem (ODE) workshop was held on July 25th-26th, 2016 at the Ronald Regan Building and International Trade Center in Washington D.C. The meeting brought together over 60 national leaders from the neurosciences, government and industry to define the needs and barriers to establishing an Open Data Ecosystem for neuroscience. The goal of the workshop was to develop a shared understanding of key challenges and opportunities in this rapidly developing landscape, and to develop coordinated strategies and priorities to best enable and capitalize on data and other resources. The main focus of the meeting was on incentives, discoverability and sustainability to accelerate brain research worldwide. The workshop produced an authoritative opinion article outlining a roadmap for building an ODE entitled "Enabling an Open Data Ecosystem for the Neurosciences," a Neuron "Neuroview" paper. A white paper to guide government agencies on how to proceed with this vital endeavor  is  currently  in its polishing stages. The workshop has generated an application to continue this work at the upcoming society for neuroscience, and several investigators have initiated collaborative programs. We hope to make this workshop a regular occurrence to forward to goal of creating and ODEN

 

The most significant results of the meeting were that the experts gathered all thought that developing an international ODEN was possible and had tremendous potential benefits.  A number of participants have embarked on solving some of the technical and logistical issues that were identified (see 2 articles above).  There was also tremendous interest by the participating foundations in furthering this agenda.  

 

1. We have initiated and energized an active working group interested in founding and maintaining an ODEN.

2. We have begun a catalog of complementary efforts that can be leveraged to push this development forward

3. We have, in progress, a whitepaper that outlines the next steps required in detail, to move this agenda forward.  We hope to disseminate this white paper to funding agencies and other entities to get support for more workshops and to begin assembling the appropriate infrastructure to make this a reality.

 

The workshop is poised to have broad impact on both the conduct of science, and on the development of basic scientific and computer science tools to enable data sharing, tracking provenance, uniform labeling of metadata, annotations, and sharing and linking anlysis code to experiments in neuroscience. The workshop will also advance our knowledge of the sociology and economics of neuroscience research, and how to optimize these parameters to maximize discovery. We expect, once the ODEN is functioning, for it to broadly impact science and discovery at the highest levels.

 

The principles discussed and action items identified at this workshop are globally applicable to all scientific fields.  With the exception of a few: genetics, particle physics, meteorology and astronomy, most scientific fields have not worked out the mechanics of data, code and metadata sharing.  We expect the work from this conference, and its products, to broadly impact these fields. 

 

The overall goal is to dramatically improve the efficiency, accuracy, reproducibility and pace of scientific discovery.  We believe that by changing incentives, improving data discoverability and putting sustainable systems in place, that this could invigorate scientific collaboration world wide and accelerate it.

 

Results have been published and disseminated to participants at the conference.  The white paper draft has just been sent to the executive board for the workshop, who will review it quickly.  We hope to then disseminate it to conference participants and interested parties in academia, government and the private sector.
